reviewText: Although Penumbra: Requiem is without the Survival aspects of Overture and Black Plague, its puzzles provide a challenge worth conquering as you unravel more about Philip and what goes on in his head.  However, due to this, the game does tend to feel more like Portal without a Portal Gun than a game from the Penumbra series. While it not may live up to expectations brought to the table by Black Plague, it's a satisfying conclusion to a great trilogy.

reviewText: If you just play Penumbra for the monsters Requiem is not for you. However, if you liked the story of Penumbra this is a great conclusion for the series.\n\nRequiem takes a whole new approach to the Penumbra series: no monsters are encountered, so instead of being a horror game with puzzle elements this is now a puzzle game with horror elements. Keep in mind that Requiem is about 4 hours long (Black Plague is about 8 and Overture is about 12) and is not Penumbra 3" but instead an expansion pack for Black Plague. Don't expect a full length story like the first two games
date: but that being said the story in Requiem is great for an expansion pack. It's actually quite scary at times
recommended: and it takes true horror craftmanship to scare the player while there is no physical threat to their character.\n\nThe puzzles are by far the best of the Penumbra series. They blow the Overture/Black Plague puzzles out of the water and are a lot of fun. They're not too hard and not too easy
hoursPlayed: which makes for a nice difficulty. Requiem is the only game in the Penumbra series where I felt the pacing was uninterrupted; don't get me wrong
voteText: Overture and Black Plague are great games but were often *plagued* by clunky action mechanics (Overture only) and occasionally bad puzzles."
votesFunny: 18 of 22 people (82%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
First of all, Penumbra: Requiem is a DLC to Black Plague, and I will review this as a DLC.

If you played Penumbra: Black Plague, you probably wondered what happened to poor unlucky Phillip. Well, you get an interesting answer in Requiem, which kind of poses more interesting questions than answers.

Requiem is all about the puzzles. There are 9 levels (puzzles) and as you solve each one, there are interesting books, artifacts, and audio recordings to discover that piece together the current reality you are experiencing. This game isn't scary like the first two in the series, but it does maintain that dark and foreboding atmosphere. Personally, I'm glad there were no monsters stalking me, since I died enough trying to solve the puzzles.

Now are the puzzles hard? Yes....and no.....sort of. The puzzles start off easy, then even though you know how to solve it, you have to execute it just right or start over. Thats where it got kind of annoying for me, since my timing can be less than great. I also like to overjump platforms a lot and jump to my death. So, if you have an excellent sense of timing and depth perception, you should have no problem.

Now there really isn't a story per se, since it just build off from the last two games. There are two endings plus an optional extra ending if you find each artifact hidden in each level. I was content to get the regular two endings and Youtube the special one, since I was in no mood to look for all the artifacts and solve the puzzles. This game gave me serious feelings of nausea since I had to repeatedly try to do puzzles correctly (jumping platforms, falling, moving puzzles).

I really enjoyed the dissent into madness and meeting" the fellow insane people that have been dropped in the facility. The sound really keeps you on edge. The graphics would only let me play on the lowest settings
date: despite me trying to change the screen resolution repeatedly. If anyone ever finds a fix let me know. This was a minor annoyance to me
recommended: since graphics in a game like this is secondary criteria.\n\nI feel a sense of accomplishment after playing this
hoursPlayed: and while it is not really a full "game" like the two previous Penumbra titles
voteText: it should be played to enrich the Penumbra experience.  I am also looking forward to playing Penumbra: Necrologue!"

reviewText: This is a timid recommendation, but I think the game is good enough to be called a decent wrap up for the series. There are no enemies at all in this game, so there is no tension. Despite that, some of the locations manage to be creepier than anything in the preceeding games. There aren't a lot of glowing positives to this title. The story is superfluous, so if you've finished Black Plague and DON'T want to play this, then you aren't missing much. The puzzles are more numerous and a bit more complex, but for the first time in the series, there are more than a few convoluted challenges.

reviewText: Disapointment.  Thats all I got after finishing the 3rd and final chapter in this series.  What started off solid in Overture and continued with a bang in Black Plauge just fizzled out here.   The spooky atmosphere is really the only thing this has in common with the first two games.  No real threat felt.  Just puzzle after puzzle after puzzle with nothing.  It offered no resolution to what the first two games.  Hell looking back I would say Black Plague was a better ending.  This was just Portal without the portal gun.  Play if you love puzzles but if you want the horror these games offered in the first two titles than you'll be disapointed like I was.

reviewText:
There are things I need of you. Things you may not understand. Please heed my words and hope you do not make the same mistakes i did.

My name is Phillip and oh dear, this mess of a game.

My story begins in January 2015. I noticed that the steam sale was on and decided that I would browse around. My eyes finally found Penumbra. It was on sale (Â£1.25). I bought it, not realising what was at the end.

Requiem was not what I was expecting. It was not Penumbra. It was a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ collection of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ puzzles.

Now I must ask of you. I promised the Tuurngait that I would leave this game in peace. You must now do what I failed to do.

Forget that this game exists. Leave it to be lost to the passage of time, but warn others to stay away. I had to perform tests for the Tuurngait, jumping through hoops like the Blobfish it saw me as. It was right: I WAS A PENUMBRA FAN!

I promised I would leave this game in peace. I Lied. I hope you have the strength to do what I failed to do.

Penumbra:Requiem is located at steam id: 22140

Kill them. Kill them all.

reviewText:
Would I recommend? Tricky. If you've played through Overture and Black Plague then you probably want to take the story to completion.

The problem really is that this installment doesn't really do that. As a standalone puzzle experience it's not a bad little game but as part of the Penumbra series it falls short.

In essence, unlike the previous games with areas that naturally followed on and progressed with a story, Requiem is split into individual unrelated puzzles. Maybe something you've encountered in a previous area will help you understand a new one but that aside there's no real flowing narrative. The whole find x number of keys to exit the area" feels a little cheap too with no real explanation.

In addition there are no enemies and not much interaction beyond pulling some boxes and turning values. Whilst some areas do have the spooky unsettling feel
date:
after you've fallen off into the water and had to swim all the way back for 15th time the atmosphere tends to wane.

So to buy? If you want a fairly short puzzle game then Requiem isn't a bad choice. However if you're looking for a solid finish to the Penumbra story I think you'll be disappointed as nothing is really added beyond the conclusion of the second game.

I'll go with "yes" because Requiem isn't a bad use of your time
recommended: but just be aware of what it is and what it isn't."

reviewText:
I Enjoyed the first two, Very stimulating, brain wracking and sometimes tough as nails test, some parts I did have to look at a walkthrough because of how...vauge some were, But the first one was very organic, It introduced itself very well.
I adored the second one, The plotline was immense, the puzzles were tough and I will admit I didn't like some (I.E. The computer bonding cards one) But it was immersive enough to keep wits about.

Unfortunately rebirth was stale, Some puzzles seem to be more time killers than actual puzzles, wait for this platform to go here is a tiring game mechanic, also this one somehow feels too similar to portal rather than think of survial like the other two felt.

I love the series, its just the first two popped so well. the last one is losing its luster because it just feels so much more...controlled than the other two.

Still recommened for the first two. 4 outta 5

reviewText: I'd say that this was the worst of the trilogy (Overture was my favorite) because it lacked the sad, grim feel of melancholy that the other two games shared. It's a feel that is unique to the Penumbra games, and I just didn't feel it much in this one. The storyline was also kinda choppy - felt more like a progression of puzzles with some dialogue lines mixed in. Still, though, this game had some really cool puzzles and environments that radiated a sort of crazy, dreamlike feel. It really felt like Philip's last step into madness. Oh, and he cracks a lot of cheesy jokes, too. Philip should have his own talk show.\nOthers may say that this is the one game of the trilogy that isn't worth playing, but I say:\nexploding ketchup.

reviewText: The third and final title in the Penumbra trilogy takes a departure from survival horror to bring players a more thoughtful and narrative-focused game. This game is not a survival horror - it is a puzzle game. While I would have liked to see an all-out horror game for Penumbra's final chapter, I do think Requiem has the best puzzles of the series. (It would have to - otherwise there would be no point in getting it.) The story is even more strange and mysterious than before, sometimes even downright confusing. However, it is still a Penumbra game and still a decent final chapter to one of the best and most underrated horror game series of all time.

reviewText: This is worth playing if you enjoyed the first two Penumbras and would like to see the conclusion further qualified and some loose ends resolved (while many others open...). I should note that this game feels quite different to either of its predecessors. It is neither horror nor sci-fi, it's basically in the mindâ™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ genre. Things will only (barely) make some sense if you have been paying close attention to the events of the first two games, so you must play those beforehand.\n\nThe game is also easier because now your flashlight has unlimited power and there are no enemies other than the environment. This actually makes sense in the context of the plot. Finish the game to see why :)

reviewText:
Penumbra: Requiem is a puzzle-focused expansion taking place after the events of Penumbra: Black Plague. The player once again takes the role of Philip, struggling to make order out of chaos, or at least to orient the chaos in the desired direction. Events are equally surreal as in BP, but overall, the environment is less tense and physically threatening.

Each area requires Philip to collect a number of mystic orbs in order to open a gateway to places better left unvisited, so that he can subsequently visit them. Along the way, he is haunted by voices from the past.

Overall, I enjoyed Requiem - it's more of a Penumbra-themed Talos Principle than a true chapter of Penumbra, but that's not a bad thing.

reviewText:
This is a puzzle game not a horror adventure game like the other two Penumbra games.

The game itself isn't too bad really. Most puzzles are good but a few of them require to much backtracking and braindead tasks, such as slowly moving items across large portions of the map.

Supposedly the game the picks up some loose ends of the Overture/Black plague story but I think it really didn't do a too good job at that. I feel the story is told the wrong way. You are doing puzzles and a voice tells you about the story virtually without any connection to the puzzles themselves.

It is almost like this game was done to keep some of Frictionals staff occupied while the rest made the foundation for Amnesia the dark descent.

Cannot recommend due to wrong expectations from me and probably most of the players who started with the other games in the Penumbra series. If you are really into physics puzzle games this might be for you though.

reviewText:
This game is the third of the Penumbra series, and I was unimpressed.

The first of the series, Overture, lacked substantial story and depth.
The second of the series, Black Plague, was shorter and simpler, but had the rich story we were looking for in the series.
The third, this Requiem, was a mistake. The game has explicitly no direction at all, no development of the story lined up from the last two in the series, and is not even fun to play. They removed the horror aspect entirely with the removal of any and all enemies.
I would say the game is broken, even, because there is virtually no substance - only a handful of bland, lackluster puzzles.

It became a chore to play this game, and I am glad to be rid of it. You need not play Requiem to appreciate the Penumbra series. Stop at Black Plague, save your money, and save the frustration.

reviewText: At first I thought it was going to be a first-person point-and-click so I got excited. But I soon learned the horrifying truth... that this would be a horror game! Environmental hazards, item puzzles, confusion, darkness and fear of the unknown... I immediately started thinking of jump scares and Amnesia, so it was a relief to learn this was made by the same creators of Amnesia so this would be a high-quality Amnesia clone by people who knew what they were doing. Because they did it before. Several times. If you like atmospheric story-heavy horror games where you run and hide like a little baby because light attracts danger, this will be right up your alley. If you're like me and would rather punch the monsters in the face or at the very least NOT have to cower and run and hide while piecing together the story, you should play Skyrim or Le Chuck's Revenge instead.

There's almost no tension, which was such a great part of previous two games. And some puzzles are quite un-intuitive. Yet there's nice design of levels and brilliant voice-acting and overall sound. Anyway, if you played Overture and Black Plague, you'll play Requiem too.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: While the game has a lack of opposition and some weird plot elements, the puzzles were thoughtful and the atmosphere probably tops both Overture and Black Plague due to how surreal and dreamlike it is in comparison. What this game manages to succeed in is making it creepy just based on how empty it is. It is actually quite an effective way to immerse a player into the game, considering the last two games had plenty of monsters to encounter. As a major contrast, this entry makes you feel truly alone.\n\nFor a more detailed review, please read this: http://breakingcanon.com/games/penumbra-requiem/

reviewText:
Started playing it with the impression it was supposed to be an actual horror game, needless to say it does not deliver on that aspect.

Some horror elements are implied, but the game never really makes use of any of it. Level one contains a dead body, and I'm pretty sure it was the only one, anyway. Sorta gave a false first impression.

That aside, decent puzzle game- but very lazily created off the main game. You still have a journal, and an inventory with a bunch of crud, and you can still go into hiding mode by crouching, but at no point in the game will you [have] to use any of it, save for maybe the painkillers if you happen to slip off an extraordinarily high ledge.

Nothing special, but if you were gonna buy Black Plague anyway you might as well give it a spin.

reviewText: Old and dated graphics aside, the environment is extremely immersive, very well paced and very worthwhile challenge.  Its a true series, each game picks up where the last game ends.  We need more games like this.\n\nSimply put, the Penumbra series is awesome.  Play all 3 games, you wont be disappointed.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: It's not like the previous games but it's still decent puzzle game on it's own. There is not much story and it makes no sense, but it's creepy. It's very short, I finished it without walkthrough in about 3 hours but it came free with the Black Plague, so this is not a problem. If you liked the puzzles in pervious games then you should try this, but if you are just interested in story then there aren't much in here, so you can skip this.

reviewText: Portal w/o cool mechanics. Box moving simulator 10/10. Puzzle game 1/10. Horror/suspense game 1/10
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: This is an interesting episode in the Penumbra series. Unlike the previous games, this one is entirely focused on puzzle solving. That is to say that there are no monsters in it. Although it is still a great game, you won't be jumping out of your seat every 5 minutes. However, in no way am I implying it is boring. The puzzles will encourage the player to think and use their environment to move ahead.\n\nConsider this an epilogue to the series, almost as if the game is finally giving you a break from all the previous horror. Instead of focusing on potential enemies, sit back, relax, and focus on the story and the conclusion to Phillip's hellish adventure.

reviewText: SHORT REVIEW INCOMING:\nDo you wanna know which Penumbra game is the weakest of the bunch? This one. It's even worse than the first installment. No horror elements this time. Just randomly secluded puzzles and a weak conclusion of the whole story in the end. I would give this game a thumbs up if the puzzles were good, but no, they're terrible.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: At first I thought it was going to be a first-person point-and-click so I got excited. But I soon learned the horrifying truth... that this would be a horror game! Environmental hazards, item puzzles, confusion, darkness and fear of the unknown... I immediately started thinking of jump scares and Amnesia, so it was a relief to learn this was made by the same creators of Amnesia so this would be a high-quality Amnesia clone by people who knew what they were doing. Because they did it before. Several times. If you like atmospheric story-heavy horror games where you run and hide like a little baby because light attracts danger, this will be right up your alley. If you're like me and would rather punch the monsters in the face or at the very least NOT have to cower and run and hide while piecing together the story, you should play Skyrim or Le Chuck's Revenge instead.

reviewText: So a quick review". PROs and CONs first. Then some comments & random notes I have about the game.\n(note
date:
my #/10 score = gameplay+graphics/sound+story etc.. + my enjoyment)

PROs:+many puzzles
+different types of puzzles (platforming
voteText:
companion cube puzzles etc..)
+atmospheric (peaceful but eerie at times)

CONs:-some puzzles are just annoying to do
-careful with elevators (my boxes bugged out)

Comments:It is a basically expansion pack for those whole like puzzles. There ain't no enemies. It is purely puzzle solving.
Most of the times puzzles were okay. There were unique puzzles in their own way and some somewhat difficult. Though few puzzles annoyed me (mostly 2 platforming spots) and few that forced back n forward running.

Aside that it was 2 hours experience for me. It was okay
